entries.title: The phantasmagorical world of Yayoi Kusama is honored in Hong Kong
entries.description: M+, Hong Kong's new museum of contemporary Asian art, celebrates its first anniversary with an exceptional retrospective of the 93-year-old Japanese artist.

entries.title: In and out of love: 'His windows are open, I want to shout his name'
entries.description: Two days in the life of lovers. The first when there is everything to play for, the second when everything gets lost. This week, Basile, 42 years old, tells his equally brief and intense story.

entries.title: 'Dark Tintin': The cursed manuscript delving into the shadows of Hergé's childhood
entries.description: No major publishing house wanted to publish Mark Alizart's essay, 'Dark Tintin', in which the philosopher offered a rereading of the young reporter's adventures in the light of the incest that his creator, Hergé, had suffered as a child.

entries.title: Football: Deschamps to keep coaching 'Les Bleus'
entries.description: The announcement was made on Saturday, as the French Football Federation is holding a federal assembly against the backdrop of an audit requested by the Sports Ministry.

entries.title: China's economy hit by mass Covid-19 infections
entries.description: Both supply and demand are affected by the scale of the infections, which are forcing customers and employees to stay home. However, the situation could improve rapidly.

entries.title: Meeting the last of the WW I 'Black Force' in Senegal
entries.description: In 1998, 'Le Monde' profiled Abdoulaye Ndiaye, the last survivor of the African riflemen regiment. Mr. Ndiaye died the same year, on the eve of receiving the French Legion of Honor.

entries.title: Lula had a parade: Does anyone care?
entries.description: On January 1, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was officially sworn in as president of Brazil for the third time. It was also an opportunity for him and his family to have an elegant parade before the ceremony.

entries.title: Iran: 'A regime that kills its children, rapes youngsters and massacres minorities has no legitimacy'
entries.description: Arrested at the age of 16 in 1981, filmmaker Sepideh Farsi recounts for 'Le Monde' how Tehran executed a multitude of young women in the 1980s.

entries.title: Canada registers record number of immigrants in 2022
entries.description: The Canadian government wants to encourage economic immigration to offset the effects of the country's aging population and labor shortages.

entries.title: France's hospital plan: A pill, if no cure, will do for now
entries.description: Proposals to improve French hospitals' working conditions presented by Emmanuel Macron on Friday are a step in the right direction. Let's hope that the plan does not come too late.

entries.title: McCarthy takes on speaker role as far right gains ground within GOP
entries.description: The Republican ended up being elected on Saturday in a late-night 15th round of voting after making extensive concessions to right-wing hardliners.

entries.title: How Frontex surveillance equipment is used by the Libyan coast guard to intercept migrants
entries.description: In a video investigation, 'Le Monde' shows how the European agency is facilitating migrant interceptions by Libyan officials in the Mediterranean.

entries.title: Didier Deschamps to remain Les Bleus coach until 2026
entries.description: Deschamps' contract expired after the World Cup in Qatar in December when France lost to Argentina in a penalty shootout after a thrilling final.

entries.title: Kurds from around Europe gather in Paris to demonstrate over killings
entries.description: The march is organized in protest of the unresolved killing of three activists in the French capital 10 years ago. Kurdish groups are also mourning the three people killed in Paris two weeks ago.

entries.title: Iran proceeds to two more executions in connection with protests
entries.description: The two men executed on Saturday were convicted of allegedly killing a paramilitary volunteer during a demonstration. Two men were already put to death in December.

entries.title: Timur Soykan, the Turkish investigative journalist disrupting authority
entries.description: The award-winning journalist has revealed the forced marriage of a 6-year-old girl and described corruption networks reaching the highest authorities of the country. He has been unanimously awarded the Press Freedom Prize 2022.

entries.title: No ceasefire in Ukraine during Orthodox Christmas despite Putin's order
entries.description: A 36-hour ceasefire unilateraly ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin was supposed to start on Friday, but artillery exchanges pounded eastern Ukraine.

entries.title: Thomas Piketty: 'It is time for the pension system to focus on small pensions'
entries.description: According to the French economist, Emmanuel Macron's pension reform, which will be presented next week, will be financed only by the most modest.

entries.title: Republican Kevin McCarthy elected US House speaker after 15th vote
entries.description: There were more rounds of voting this year than in any speaker election since the Civil War.

entries.title: Ronald Chammah, the discreet go-between of French auteur cinema
entries.description: Unlike his spouse Isabelle Huppert, his name is unknown to the general public. As the owner of two arthouse cinemas in Paris, the producer and distributor tirelessly defends repertory cinema.

entries.title: Remadji Hoinathy: 'In Chad, France doesn't seem to understand anything other than preserving stability'
entries.description: 'From Dakar to Djibouti, a tour of the Africa-France relationship' (8/11). The Chadian anthropologist believes we need to go beyond the 'mechanical perception,' which has put his country 'on a knife edge,' meaning it 'could topple over at any moment.'

entries.title: US House of Representatives: Uproar on the House floor as McCarthy comes up short in 14th vote
entries.description: Fingers pointed, insults shouted and colleagues being restrained, but there is still no speaker of the US House of Representatives after 14 votes.

entries.title: Rural French fire stations are desperate for volunteers
entries.description: In the countryside, emergency stations run almost exclusively through volunteers, but they are forced to fill in for other public services as the effects of climate disruption are increasingly felt.

entries.title: At the Cernuschi Museum in Paris, a rediscovery of Chinese ink paintings from the 20th century
entries.description: Seventy works by some 30 artists have been brought together to illustrate the evolution of a traditional technique against a tumultuous historical timeline.

entries.title: Could the British Museum soon return disputed Parthenon friezes to Greece?
entries.description: For 40 years, Athens has been asking London to return a 75-meter frieze from the famous ancient relic. The UK claims that the marbles were legally acquired, while Greece maintains they were looted. A historic agreement is underway.

entries.title: Samsung: 'Sharpest decline in eight years'
entries.description: The South Korean company warned that its profits hit rock bottom for the last quarter of 2022. Furthermore, Philippe Escande, economic editorialist at 'Le Monde' observes that the microchip market is entering a recession.

entries.title: In France, hospitals are being asked to reduce their carbon footprint
entries.description: While the health sector constitutes about 8% of France's CO2 emissions, the state is helping health care institutions to reduce their energy consumption.

entries.title: Biden honors police officers on second anniversary of Capitol assault
entries.description: During a somber White House ceremony, President Joe Biden decried voter intimidation and political violence.

entries.title: Lubmin, the German village where the pipeline runs dry
entries.description: On the Baltic Sea coast, the village is the endpoint for the Nord Stream pipelines through which Germany can tap into cheap Russian gas. But since the war in Ukraine, the tap has been turned off.

entries.title: War in Ukraine: The US will send a record $3.75 billion in military aid to Kiev
entries.description: The direct assistance for Ukraine includes a multitude of key weapons including 50 Bradley armored vehicles and 500 anti-tank missiles.
